original_query:
Query 1: Find top 5 papers on LLMs this year (2025), and give a short summary in html format. Response 1:

Here are summaries of the top 5 papers on LLMs published in 2025:

  • Proof or Bluff? Evaluating LLMs on 2025 USA Math Olympiad
    A Computer Science paper titled "Proof or Bluff? Evaluating LLMs on 2025 USA Math Olympiad" (Jasper Dekoninck) introduces a comprehensive evaluation of LLMs' full-solution reasoning on the 2025 USAMO problems. Results show state-of-the-art models struggled significantly, indicating current LLMs are inadequate for rigorous mathematical reasoning and proof generation.
    Source: arxiv.org/abs/2503.21934
  • NeurIPS 2025 - LLM Usage Policy
    NeurIPS 2025 allows LLMs in paper preparation, but authors must document LLM use in methodology if significant and are responsible for content correctness, originality, and scientific integrity. LLMs cannot be authors; only humans are eligible.
    Source: neurips.cc/Conferences/2025/LLM
  • ICLR (International Conference on Learning Representations)
    ICLR includes various resources such as FAQs, contact information, downloads, and information about the conference. Users can browse papers with various layouts and sort by title, author, topic, or session.
    Source: iclr.cc/virtual/2025/papers.html
  • Weekly Top LLM Papers - 2025
    This repository documents weekly learnings from LLM research papers, focusing on staying updated, deepening understanding, and sharing insights. It contains a curated list of foundational LLM papers.
    Source: github.com/youssefHosni/Weekly-Top-LLM-Papers/blob/main/Weekly-Top-LLM-Papers-2025.md
  • Summary Unavailable
    An error occurred while attempting to summarize this paper.
Query 2: Can you talk more about the second paper mentioned there, NeurIPS 2025 - LLM Usage Policy? Give me more details about this one.

raw_text.text:
[trafilatura] NeurIPS 2025 Policy on the Use of Large Language Models
Program Chairs: Nancy Chen, Marzyeh Ghassemi, Piotr Koniusz, Razvan Pascanu, Hsuan-Tien Lin;
Assistant Program Chairs: Elena Burceanu, Junhao Dong, Zhengyuan Liu, Po-Yi Lu, Isha Puri
NeurIPS 2025 LLM Policy for Authors
Use of Large Language Models (LLMs): We welcome authors to use any tool that is suitable for preparing high-quality papers and research. However, we ask authors to keep in mind two important criteria. First, we expect authors to document their methodology clearly for upholding scientific rigorousness and transparency standards. The use of LLMs in implementing the method should be described in the experimental setup section (or equivalent) if it is an important, original, or non-standard component of the approach. The use of spell checkers and grammar suggestions, programming aid for editing purposes does not need to be documented. Second, authors are responsible for the entire content of the paper, including all text, figures, and references. Therefore, while authors are welcome to use any tool they wish for preparing and writing the paper, they must ensure that all content is correct and original.
All authors should take full responsibility to understand the advantages and limitations of using any tools and resources when preparing their scientific publications. Some (including free) tools may retain input data for further model training purposes, so authors should exercise caution to account for individual privacy considerations. High-level instructions could potentially result in hallucinations when generating plots, risking scientific integrity. It is the authors responsibility to verify the tools are used in a scientifically responsible manner.
NeurIPS reserves the right to investigate at any time whether the Code of Conduct was adhered to, including after paper acceptance, publication, or the conference. If an investigation determines a violation, NeurIPS reserves the right to revoke the paper's publication status. Examples of such violations include content that is not scientifically sound (e.g. using references generated by an LLM without conducting the due diligence to verify correctness, existence and appropriateness in the manuscripts context)..
FAQ
1. Can I use Large Language Models (LLMs) while preparing my paper?
Yes, you are welcome to use any tool, including LLMs, to prepare for your publications. However, you must describe the use of these tools clearly if they are part of your methodology. If you use tools (including LLMs) for editing purposes (e.g. checking grammar), you do not need to declare it in your manuscript.
2. If I used LLMs to help me prepare my manuscript, can I add it as one of the Authors?
No. Only humans are eligible to be authors. You, as an author, are fully responsible for all the content in your paper, including text, figures, and methodology, regardless of what tools (e.g., LLMs) you have used. You must ensure that:
- All content is correc

perception.result_requirement: Summaries of top 5 LLM papers published in 2025 in html format.
perception.reasoning: The initial query aimed to find and summarize the top 5 LLM papers of 2025.  The response provides summaries of 4 papers and indicates a failure to summarize the 5th. The follow-up question asks for more detail on the second paper. Since the initial goal isn't fully achieved and further detail is requested, more planning is needed.
perception.local_reasoning: The initial query for the top 5 LLM papers resulted in a list with summaries for 4 out of 5 papers and a follow-up question about one of the listed papers. This indicates that the initial query is not entirely fulfilled and more information is requested, necessitating further action.

data.description: Extract more details about the NeurIPS 2025 - LLM Usage Policy paper from the provided URL.

perception.reasoning: The initial query asked for the top 5 LLM papers of 2025 and their summaries in HTML format. A follow-up question requested more details about the NeurIPS 2025 paper. The latest step provided the raw text for the NeurIPS paper. Now, we have enough information to fully address both the original query and the follow-up question. We can now summarize the top 5 papers, including the detailed information for the NeurIPS paper, and format the result in HTML.
perception.local_reasoning: We now have the original summaries of 4 papers, a message saying one failed to summarize, and the raw text for the NeurIPS 2025 paper. Thus we can summarize all the things in markdown format and return it.
perception.last_tooluse_summary: Raw text extracted successfully using trafilatura.
perception.instruction_to_summarize: Create a final summary of the top 5 LLM papers published in 2025. Include the detailed information extracted from the NeurIPS 2025 paper's raw text. Mention that there was an error while summarizing the last paper. Provide the complete output in HTML format. Use information extracted within the globals_schema to summarize the papers.

data.description: Search for additional information about the NeurIPS 2025 - LLM Usage Policy paper.
Combine the extracted and searched information to provide a comprehensive summary in HTML format.
